content: Search Free Trial Get Demo 19 Best Practices for Securing Microsoft Office 365 February 16, 2022 Microsoft Office 365 is a massive platform that many businesses use. It is considered the worlds most popular office suite of productivity tools. Unfortunately, this means it is a hugely popular target for cyber-attackers as well. Microsoft Office 365 has a variety of effective built-in security features but it often needs specialized add-ons to address sophisticated threats like business email compromise and targeted phishing. Its important to learn how to configure and deploy these security features, and train employees, so you can protect your sensitive business data. Lets take a look at the features you can enable, and steps you can take to make sure your Office 365 is secure. 1. Utilize Multi-Factor Authentication Utilizing multifactor authentication is the easiest, most effective way to rapidly improve your organizations security. When you log in, youll need to type a code from your mobile device in order to access Microsoft Office 365 . Adding this step helps prevent hackers from taking over an account if they discover the password or trick a user with a phishing attack. This can also be called 2-step verification. 2. Use Separate Admin Accounts The admin accounts you use for your Office 365 environment include elevated privileges, making them valuable targets for cybercriminals. Admins need to have separate user accounts for regular, everyday use  only using their admin account as necessary to complete tasks associated with job functions. Creating an emergency access admin account can also be helpful in case a problem arises. Additionally, assign Role-Based Access Control RBAC for admins can be helpful. 3. Train Your Employees While Office 365 has so many features which help improve overall security and compliance, these controls do not necessarily address the most dangerous threats that face every organization, which is human error. In a report done by Stanford , they found that approximately 88 percent of all data breaches are caused by an employee mistake. To address the severity of human error, organizations have made investments in Office 365 security and awareness training. However, to err is human so organizations need to plan for the failure and not expect them to detect all attacks, all the time. 4. Protect Against Ransomware Attacks A ransomware attack acts to restrict access to your companys data by encrypting files or even locking computer screens. Ransomware will then attempt to extort money from the victims by asking for ransom. This is typically in the form of cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin, in exchange for data access. The Safe Attachments feature of Microsoft 365 Defender can catch advanced ransomware but it comes at the cost of delayed delivery of attachments and user experience. 5. Raise the Level of Malware Protection The Office 365 environment includes malware protection , however, you can increase this protection when blocking attachments with commonly used malware file types. Its important to note that the most common malware file types are PDF and Office Documents. 6. Stop Email Auto-Forwarding Attackers gaining access to a users mailbox might exfiltrate mail by configuring a mailbox that automatically forwards emails. This can occur without the users awareness. This can be prevented by configuring mail flow rules instead. Spend less time investigating suspicious messages and remediating threats. Download the Report 7. Use Office 365 Message Encryption Office 365 Message Encryption is an included feature with Microsoft 365 thats already fully set up. With this feature, your business can send and receive encrypted emails. Office 365 message encryption allows you to ensure only intended recipients can view the message content. 8. Protect Email Accounts from Phishing Attacks If you have configured custom domains for your Microsoft Office 365 environment, you can also configure targeted anti-phishing protection . Anti-phishing solutions can help protect your business from any malicious phishing attack . If you have not configured custom domains, you will not need to do this. 9. Protect from Malicious Attachments  Files with O365 Safe Attachments People often send, receive, and share attachments, like documents, presentations, and sheets. It can be difficult to tell if an attachment is safe or malicious. Office 365 Safe Attachments protection is not turned on by default, but it should be because this protection extends to all files in SharePoint, OneDrive, and Microsoft Teams. 10. Protect Against Phishing Attacks by Using Safe Links Attackers can use malicious websites links in email or other files. Safe Links for Office 365 helps protect your business  providing time-of-clickverification of web URLs within email messages and Office documents. Safe Links cannot protect against zero-day phishing threats. Items to Enable There are multiple different features in O365 that can be enabled in order to make your organization more secure. These include 11. Unified Audit Log The unified audit log holds all user, group, application, domain, and directory activities that are performed in the Microsoft 365 admin center. 12. Alert Policies An alert policy contains a set of rules defining the user activity generating alerts, as well as a list of users who triggered the alert if the activity is performed. 13. Azure Portal Inactivity Timeout This etting protects resources from unauthorized access when you forget to secure your workstation. 14. External Email Tagging This feature clearly marks all external emails as External in order to alert mail users to be cautious with the attachments and contents of the message. Items to Block In addition to the items that should be enabled in O365, there are items you should pay attention to blocking in order to keep your email secure. These may include 15. Legacy Authentication Protocols Legacy authentication protocols cant enforce certain rules, making them a preferred entry points for hackers attacking your organization. 16. User Consent to Apps Giving consent to unmanaged apps can pose a threat to your organization. 17. User access to Azure Portal You will only want admins to have access the Azure portal. Its not relevant for regular users to have access, and could pose a threat. 18. Guest can invite access Similarly to the items above, this could pose a threat if there was a hacked account in your organization or another that you work with. 19. Check Out the O365 Security and Compliance Center The Security and Compliance Center for O365 has many different tools to help you keep your sensitive data secure. When you wonder what else you can do to protect your business, this is always a great option to check in on new opportunities. Final Thoughts A crucial part of keeping Microsoft Office 365 secure is regularly checking the audit logs and keeping up with security recommendations in the Microsoft 365 Security Center. These layers help protect individuals leveraging O365, however, it is also the responsibility of each organization using 365 to make sure their implementation and configuration is configured securely. All organizations should review, configure and tune the appropriate security settings in various areas of Microsoft Office 365s services to make sure the proper risk tolerance levels are met. **Comprehensive Analysis of Microsoft Office 365 Security Article**

**1. Key Security Features and Their Benefits**

- **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):** Enhances security by requiring a second form of verification, preventing unauthorized access even if a password is compromised.
- **Separate Admin Accounts:** Reduces risk by limiting the use of high-privilege accounts to essential tasks only, mitigating potential damage from breaches.
- **Safe Attachments:** Scans attachments for malware, ensuring safer file sharing and reducing the risk of ransomware attacks.

**2. Compliance Certifications and Regulatory Adherence**

- While the article does not specify particular certifications, Microsoft Office 365 is known to comply with regulations like GDPR and ISO 27001. Features such as audit logs and encryption support compliance efforts, aiding organizations in meeting regulatory requirements.

**3. User-Focused Security Recommendations**

- **Employee Training:** Regular security awareness training to reduce human error, a leading cause of data breaches.
- **Anti-Phishing Protection:** Configure settings to detect and block phishing attempts, protecting against email-based threats.
- **Message Encryption:** Ensures only intended recipients can read emails, safeguarding sensitive information.

**4. Technical Security Implementation Details**

- **Enable Safe Attachments:** Configure to scan all attachments, enhancing malware detection.
- **Mail Flow Rules:** Set up rules to prevent email auto-forwarding, reducing data exfiltration risks.
- **Alert Policies:** Define rules to monitor and notify on suspicious activities, enabling prompt action.

**5. Data Protection Measures**

- **Encryption:** Use built-in encryption for emails and attachments to protect data in transit and at rest.
- **Audit Logs:** Regularly review logs to detect and respond to security incidents, ensuring accountability and compliance.
- **Regular Backups:** Implement backup solutions to recover data in case of ransomware attacks or system failures.

**6. Best Practices for End Users**

- **Use MFA:** Enable MFA to add an extra layer of account security.
- **Be Cautious with Emails:** Avoid opening suspicious emails or clicking on links from unknown sources.
- **Avoid Suspicious Links:** Hover over links to verify authenticity before clicking, preventing phishing attacks.

This structured approach ensures a comprehensive understanding of Office 365 security, balancing technical measures with user education to create a robust security posture.
analyses.product:
**Analysis of Microsoft Office 365 Security Features**

**1. Key Security Features and Capabilities**

- **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):** Enhances security by requiring a second form of verification, such as a code sent to a mobile device, reducing unauthorized access risks.
- **Separate Admin Accounts and RBAC:** Ensures admin privileges are used only when necessary, minimizing potential damage from compromised accounts. Role-Based Access Control limits permissions to necessary tasks.
- **Safe Attachments and Safe Links:** These features scan files and URLs in real-time to detect and block malicious content, protecting against phishing and ransomware.
- **Message Encryption:** Ensures emails are securely encrypted, preventing unauthorized access to sensitive information.
- **Unified Audit Log:** Provides a centralized log of all activities, aiding in monitoring and compliance efforts.

**2. User Benefits and Protection Measures**

- **Enhanced Security:** MFA and RBAC protect against unauthorized access, while Safe Attachments and Links guard against malware and phishing.
- **Incident Response:** Audit logs help track activities, aiding in the detection and response to security incidents.
- **Confidentiality:** Encryption ensures that communications remain private and secure.

**3. Integration with Existing Security Systems**

- **Azure Portal and Security Centers:** These tools integrate with Microsoft's ecosystem, offering a unified approach to security management. They can also connect with broader security solutions, though specific details may vary.

**4. Compliance and Certification Details**

While not explicitly listed, features like audit logs, encryption, and access controls support compliance with standards such as GDPR and ISO 27001 by providing necessary monitoring and protection mechanisms.

**5. Security Best Practices for Users**

- **Employee Training:** Essential to mitigate human error, a leading cause of breaches.
- **Regular Audits and Monitoring:** Utilize the Security and Compliance Center for proactive monitoring.
- **Software Updates:** Keep all systems updated to protect against known vulnerabilities.
- **Feature Enablement:** Ensure MFA and Safe Attachments are enabled to enhance security.

**6. Technical Specifications and Requirements**

- **Safe Attachments:** Requires enabling, as it is not active by default.
- **MFA Setup:** Needs mobile devices for 2FA.
- **Licensing:** Some features, like Safe Links, may require specific Microsoft 365 plans.
- **Azure Configuration:** Necessary for setting up inactivity timeouts and access controls.

This structured approach ensures a comprehensive understanding of Office 365's security capabilities, benefiting both organizations and users by enhancing protection and compliance.

### **Essential Microsoft Office 365 Security Guide**

#### **1. Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**
   - **What**: MFA adds an extra layer of security by requiring a second form of verification (e.g., a code sent to your phone) when logging in.
   - **Why**: Protects against password compromise and phishing attacks.
   - **How**: Enable MFA for all user accounts, especially admin accounts, in the Azure Active Directory portal.

#### **2. Use Strong, Unique Passwords**
   - **What**: Avoid reusing passwords across multiple accounts.
   - **Why**: Prevents a breach in one service from compromising your Office 365 account.
   - **How**: Use a password manager to generate and store complex passwords.

#### **3. Train Employees Regularly**
   - **What**: Conduct phishing simulations and security awareness training.
   - **Why**: Human error is a leading cause of data breaches.
   - **How**: Use Microsoft’s built-in training resources or third-party tools for ongoing education.

#### **4. Use Separate Admin Accounts**
   - **What**: Create dedicated admin accounts for administrative tasks.
   - **Why**: Reduces the risk of exposing high-privilege accounts to everyday risks.
   - **How**: Use standard accounts for regular work and switch to admin accounts only when necessary.

#### **5. Configure Safe Attachments and Safe Links**
   - **What**: Use Microsoft Defender’s Safe Attachments for scanning files and Safe Links to check URLs.
   - **Why**: Prevents malicious files and links from compromising your environment.
   - **How**: Enable these features in the Microsoft 365 Defender portal.

#### **6. Monitor and Audit**
   - **What**: Enable and review the Unified Audit Log and set up alert policies.
   - **Why**: Helps detect and respond to suspicious activities quickly.
   - **How**: Use the Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center to monitor logs.

#### **7. Protect Against Ransomware**
   - **What**: Use regular data backups and enable OneDrive’s file recovery features.
   - **Why**: Ensures business continuity in case of ransomware attacks.
   - **How**: Test backups and ensure files can be restored quickly.

#### **8. Use Office 365 Message Encryption**
   - **What**: Encrypt sensitive emails sent within and outside your organization.
   - **Why**: Protects confidential information from being intercepted.
   - **How**: Enable encryption in the Exchange admin center.

#### **9. Block Legacy Authentication**
   - **What**: Disable outdated authentication methods like IMAP, POP, and SMTP.
   - **Why**: Legacy protocols can’t enforce MFA, making accounts vulnerable.
   - **How**: Block legacy authentication in Azure AD.

#### **10. Regularly Update Software**
   - **What**: Keep Office 365 apps and related software up to date.
   - **Why**: Patches vulnerabilities and protects against exploits.
   - **How**: Enable automatic updates in your Office 365 settings.

---

### **Data Protection Recommendations**
- **Backup Data**: Regularly back up critical files stored in OneDrive and SharePoint.
- **Data Loss Prevention (DLP)**: Use Microsoft’s DLP tools to monitor and block sensitive data from being shared unintentionally.
- **Block Unwanted Apps**: Restrict user consent to unapproved third-party apps in Azure AD.

---

### **Safe Usage Guidelines**
- **Spot Phishing Attempts**: Teach users to verify sender details and never click on suspicious links or download unknown attachments.
- **Avoid Auto-Forwarding**: Disable automatic email forwarding to external domains.
- **Use Role-Based Access**: Only grant necessary permissions to users and apps.

---

### **Common Security Risks and Prevention**
- **Phishing Attacks**: Use anti-phishing policies and educate users to recognize suspicious emails.
- **Ransomware**: Enable Safe Attachments and regularly back up data.
- **Insufficient Permissions**: Review permissions and remove access for users who no longer need it.
- **External Email Threats**: Use External Email Tagging to flag emails from outside your organization.

---

### **Privacy Protection Measures**
- **Encrypt Sensitive Data**: Use encryption for emails and files containing personal or confidential information.
- **Limit Guest Access**: Disable guest access for SharePoint and Teams unless necessary.
- **Monitor Azure Portal Access**: Restrict access to the Azure portal to only authorized admins.

---

### **When to Seek Additional Security Support**
- If you detect a security breach or suspicious activity.
- When implementing advanced security configurations.
- If your organization requires compliance with industry regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.
- For incidents involving ransomware or phishing attacks.
- When deploying custom security policies or monitoring solutions.

---

By following these practical guidelines, you can significantly improve the security of your Microsoft Office 365 environment. Remember, security is an ongoing process, so regularly review and update your configurations to stay protected.
